tips.text: Make sure your bedroom is quiet, dark, and relaxing.
Keep your sleeping quarters at a temperature near 65°F (18.3°C).
Remove electronic devices such as TVs, computers, and smartphones from the bedroom.
Avoid large meals, caffeine, and alcohol before bedtime.
Being physically active during the day can help you fall asleep more easily at night.
Cooler room temperatures aid in sleep as your body temperature naturally drops during sleep.
Keep naps to 30 minutes or less and not too close to bedtime.
Avoid electronic devices in the lead-up to bedtime.
Stick to a consistent sleep and wake schedule.
Use the bedroom for sleep only.
If you cannot sleep after 20 minutes, try going to another room and only return to bed once you feel sleepy.
Choose appropriate bedtime snacks.
Smartphone overuse is tied to poor self-reported sleep quality.
Eating a low-calorie snack of carbs or protein before bed can boost metabolism in the morning.
Magnesium is believed to play a role in regulating the body's timekeeping system and may have benefits for sleep.
Drinking a protein smoothie before bed may help with muscle repair.
Hot or cold oatmeal might help prepare your body for sleep and keep you full throughout the night.
Consumption of pineapple, oranges, and bananas may be beneficial.
Melatonin production is typically increased about two hours later.
In one study, adults with self-reported sleep problems were instructed to eat two kiwis an hour before bedtime.
High-sodium diets are linked to poorer sleep quality.
Including calcium in your diet can make it easier to fall asleep and lead to more restorative sleep.
Taking a warm bath or shower could also help sleep.
Setting a sleep schedule helps them fall asleep easier.
Waking up and going to bed at the same times each day can help your internal clock keep a regular schedule.
Experience both daylight and darkness.
Irregular light exposure can lead to the disruption of circadian rhythms, making it harder to fall asleep and stay awake.
Practice yoga, meditation, and mindfulness.
When people are stressed, they tend to have difficulty falling asleep.
Yoga, meditation, and mindfulness are tools to calm the mind and relax the body.
Meditation can enhance melatonin levels and assist the brain in achieving a specific state conducive to easily achieving sleep.
Avoid looking at your clock, as clock-watching is common among people with insomnia.
Due to poor sleep at night, people with insomnia tend to be sleepy during the day, which often leads to daytime napping.
A 1996 study found that older adults who napped frequently had lower quality nighttime sleep.
Daytime napping leads to shorter sleep duration and lower sleep efficiency.
High-carb meals may be detrimental to getting a good night’s rest.
Music can significantly improve the quality of sleep.
Listening to Buddhist music may be another great tool for improving sleep.
Physical activity is often considered beneficial for healthy sleep.
It’s important to maintain a moderate-intensity exercise routine and avoid overdoing it.
To promote better quality sleep, working out early in the morning appears to be better than working out later in the day.
Get moving with activities like running, hiking, cycling, and tennis in the morning.
A comfortable mattress and bedding can have a remarkable effect on the depth and quality of sleep.
A medium-firm mattress has been shown to positively affect sleep quality, prevent sleep disturbances, and alleviate muscular discomfort.
Orthopedic pillows may be better for sleep quality than feather or memory foam pillows.
The use of a weighted blanket could reduce bodily stress and help improve your sleep.
Using electronic devices late at night is detrimental to sleep.
Electronic devices emit blue light, which has been found to suppress melatonin production.
Blocking the blue light with eyeglasses or a screen filter can be helpful.
Try aromatherapy, as essential oils may aid in relaxation.
The use of oil blends containing ingredients like lemon and orange was effective in improving sleep quality.
An essential oil diffuser could be helpful in infusing your room with relaxing scents that promote sleep.
Journaling and focusing on positive thoughts can calm the mind and help you sleep better.
Journaling has been shown to reduce bedtime worry and stress, increase sleep time, and improve sleep quality.
Limit your caffeine intake and drink a soothing beverage.
Caffeine can have a disastrous effect on your sleep quality and duration.
Avoid consuming caffeine at least 6 hours before bedtime.
Chamomile tea has been shown to promote sleep and relaxation.
Your body position during the night may affect the quality of your sleep.
Back sleepers tend to have better sleep quality.
The side sleeping position seems to be linked to high-quality sleep.
Reading could be a good activity to help you wind down before bed.
Bedtime reading may promote longer periods of sleep.
Electronic books emit blue light, which reduces the secretion of melatonin.
Lowered melatonin levels can make it harder for you to fall asleep and cause you to feel tired the next day.
Read from a physical book in order to relax and improve your sleep.
The stress and anxiety produced by forcing yourself to fall asleep can prevent you from relaxing and dozing off.
Using paradoxical intention, such as focusing on trying to stay awake, can help individuals fall asleep faster.
In one insomnia study, participants were able to fall asleep faster after they were instructed to use an imagery distraction technique.
Imagining a peaceful and relaxing environment can divert your mind from racing thoughts and help you sleep better.
Magnesium helps activate the neurotransmitters that are responsible for sleep.
Melatonin, which is a naturally occurring hormone, can be taken as a supplement to regulate sleep patterns.
Having trouble falling and staying asleep can not only be frustrating, but it can also have an impact on your mental and physical health.
